title: Disparate Postnatal Ontogenies Do Not Add to the Shape Disparity of Infants
abstract: Integrating studies of ontogeny with analyses of disparity can reveal important and surprising insights into the origins of disparity and why it varies among groups. One such potentially surprising insight is that disparity could be constant over ontogeny even though species differ in both rates and timings of development and in their ontogenetic changes in shape. Several studies of both primates and rodents have concluded that disparity is generated prenatally although some have concluded that it arises postnatally. However, neither constancy nor an ontogenetic increase in disparity has been ever been rigorously documented for either primates or rodents. For a small sample of rodents, we show that species differ in their postnatal ontogenies but infants are neither more nor less disparate than adults and the major dimensions of disparity distinguishing the main clades also do not change. The constancy in both the level of disparity and its main dimensions does not result primarily from the subtlety of postnatal differences. Those differences are indeed subtle but the disparity in directions of ontogenetic shape change is nonetheless sufficient to increase shape disparity significantly. Disparity does not increase postnatally primarily because ontogenies are not strictly linear; disparity generated postnatally counteracts that produced earlier. What limits the progressive accumulation of disparity is the curvature of ontogenetic trajectories, a curvature presumably due to ontogenetic changes in the spatial distribution of rates of bone deposition and resorption.

abstract.text: Integrating studies of ontogeny with analyses of disparity can reveal important and surprising insights into the origins of disparity and why it varies among groups. One such potentially surprising insight is that disparity could be constant over ontogeny even though species differ in both rates and timings of development and in their ontogenetic changes in shape. body_text.text: A major aim of evolutionary biology is to explain why some clades are more disparate than others. Most studies focus on the disparity of adult size and shape but studies of ontogeny could make a useful and distinctive contribution to understanding disparity, and several recent studies have called for integrating analyses of ontogenetic allometry and disparity (e.g., Crônier and Congreve 2013; Gerber 2014; Piras et al. 2011; Wilson 2013) . Development, if not ontogeny, has been a main theme of studies that examine the macroevolutionary role of variability, especially the impact and evolution of morphological integration and modularity (e.g., Goswami et al. 2014; Denton and Adams 2015; Smith et al. 2015; Alvarez et al. 2015; Monteiro and Nogueira 2009) . Ontogeny, however, could provide novel insights into the origins of disparity because disparity arises from evolutionary changes in ontogeny, making ontogenetic allometry a natural bridge between analyses of ontogeny and disparity of size and shape. Not only would incorporating analyses of disparity in studies of ontogenetic allometry add information missing from conventional studies of disparity, it would also add information missing from conventional studies of ontogenetic allometry because those typically determine only in what, and by how much, species differ in their ontogenies. What is missing is the information about the impact of those changes on disparity.

Measuring the impact of disparate ontogenies on the disparity of morphology is needed to document a surprising conclusion drawn from many comparative studies of ontogeny: that most (or even all) of adult disparity is already present by the youngest developmental stage examined, except, perhaps, for that due to differences in developmental rate or timing (e.g., Ackermann and Krovitz 2002; Voss and Marcus 1992; Young 2008; Cole 1992; Boughner and Dean 2008; Cardini and Thorington 2006; Bjorklund 1996; Klingenberg 1998; Klingenberg and Ekau 1996; Klingenberg and Spence 1993; Verzi et al. 2010; Falsetti and Cole 1992) . There is no convincing explanation for that pattern, although it is consistent with the generalization that there is more flexibility for changes in early development, and for changes in overall developmental rate or timing, than for changes in relative growth rates that alter the direction of allometric growth (Klingenberg 1998) . What makes this pattern so difficult to explain is not the high disparity generated early in development but rather the modest impact of differences in direction of later growth that indicate evolutionary changes in the spatiotemporal patterns of growth. Although some of the studies emphasizing the impact of early development on disparity failed to detect differences in the direction of later growth, others recognize that species differ but nonetheless conclude that disparity arises early in development. The difficulty is thus to explain not just why early development generates high disparity but also why later growth does not even when species develop along different directions.

There are several explanations for the greater flexibility of early development, including higher evolvability of early development and/or tighter functional constraints on later development. One hypothesis for tightening functional constraints is that the complex biomechanical adjustments required to maintain effective masticatory function constrain weanlings but not embryos that need not function as biomechanically integrated wholes (Voss and Marcus 1992) . Alternatively, late development might be contingent on early development as suggested by developmental studies that trace the disparity of skeletal shape as far back as the process initiating skeletogenesis: mesenchymal condensation (Gruneberg and des Wickramaratne 1974) . Differences arising at such early stages of the process may drive the direction of postnatal growth (Young 2008) . Still another explanation is that natural selection targets the adult shape and indirectly affects early development, an explanation that presumes high genetic correlations between developmental stages (Price and Grant 1985) . A simpler explanation denies the basic premise of the generalization, i.e., the greater flexibility of early development. This explanation is based on the observation that developmental rates decrease over ontogeny (e.g., Zelditch et al. 2003a; Hingst-Zaher et al. 2000; Swiderski and Zelditch 2013; Fischer-Rousseau et al. 2009; Loy et al. 2001 ). Because of those higher rates, even modest differences in early development would have a larger impact on disparity than later, when developmental rates are low.

Countering all these explanations are the several studies that measure disparity at two or more stages because these document significant and often substantial changes in disparity over ontogeny. Several find that disparity increases over ontogeny, such as a doubling of disparity of craniofacial shape of eared seals (Otariidae) (Sanfelice and Freitas 2007) and even a quintupling of the disparity of damselfish neurocranial shape (Frederich and Vandewalle 2011) . Decreases can be equally impressive, such as a halving of body shape disparity in piranhas (Zelditch et al. 2003b) and an even larger decrease in the disparity of cranial shape in lacertid lizards (Ponssa and Candioti 2012) . However, none of these studies examine groups in which disparity is thought to be established largely (or entirely) by birth, most notably primates and rodents. Several recent studies, using modern methods of shape analysis, have shown that primates differ in their ontogenies of shape (Cobb and O'Higgins 2004; Collard and O'Higgins 2001; Mitteroecker et al. 2004; O'Higgins et al. 2001; Singleton 2002; Singleton et al. 2010; Strand Vioarsdottir and Cobb 2004) , but none have shown that disparity increases over ontogeny. Rodents, too, demonstrably differ in their ontogenies of shape; even species of Marmota, the least disparate clade of squirrels (Zelditch et al. 2015) , differ in directions of craniofacial and mandibular ontogeny (Cardini and O'Higgins 2005; Cardini and Thorington 2006 ). Yet, disparity of rodent craniofacial form is thought to be constant, or nearly so, after birth (Cardini and O'Higgins 2005; Cardini and Thorington 2006; Verzi et al. 2010; Voss and Marcus 1992) , although it is also argued that the disparity of adults arises from the disparity of postnatal allometries (Wilson 2013; Wilson and Sanchez-Villagra 2010) .

The conflicting conclusions drawn about the origins of disparity of rodents could be due to actual biological differences among the groups studied or even to the rates at which developmental processes evolve. The studies that trace disparity to early development are narrower in scope than the two that emphasize the role of disparate allometries. Of those that trace disparity to early development, two focus on species of Marmota (Cardini and O'Higgins 2005; Cardini and Thorington 2006) and one is restricted to species of Ctenomys (Verzi et al. 2010) . One is far broader, including two species from each of seven genera representing seven tribes of South American muroids (Voss and Marcus 1992) but it is the congeneric species that are examined most closely. Hence, it remains possible that the divergence of more distant relatives might not be established at birth. One of the two studies that trace disparity of adult form to disparate postnatal allometries sampled 17 species from each of two suborders Myormopha and Ctenohystricomorpha (Wilson and Sanchez-Villagra 2010) , and the other also includes 17 species of Sciuromorpha (Wilson 2013) . However, neither of those studies examined the disparity of neonates, leaving open the possibility that the disparity of adult form arises largely from divergence of early development, perhaps accentuated postnatally by the divergence of postnatal allometries.

In this study, we compare postnatal ontogenies of eight species of rodents, two myomorphs and six sciuromorphs. This tiny sample of the most diverse group of mammals cannot address the question: is the disparity of rodent shape constant over postnatal ontogeny? However, by including representatives of two suborders, and several closely related species in one suborder, we can address one question raised by the contrasts among previous studies, because studies that are more limited in phylogenetic scope favor the hypothesis that much or nearly all of disparity arises prenatally whereas broader studies emphasize allometric disparity as the cause of adult disparity. If early development plays the dominant role in generating the disparity of close relatives but not of more distant relatives in older clades, we would not expect constancy of disparity in our sample. We first compare ontogenies to determine by how much species differ in shape at birth, in their ontogenies of shape (due to differences in allometric patterns) and in rates of shape change and overall length of their ontogenetic trajectories. We then use simulations to quantify how much disparity would arise from each modification, taken separately and together, as well as how much disparity would arise if early development differs by no more than postnatal development does. To determine whether the ontogenetic dynamics of disparity that we discern in the analysis spanning two suborders owes to the large differences between sciuromorphs and myomorphs, we measure disparities for the sample as a whole and for just the six squirrels. We show that constancy of disparity is a realistic possibility even though postnatal growth is disparate both in allometric patterns and rates/timing.

The eight species analyzed in this study include two myomorphs, one an Old World muroid (the laboratory mouse Mus musculus domesticus), and the other a New World muroid (a cotton rat, Sigmodon fulviventer). The other six are sciuromorphs from three tribes of squirrels (Sciuridae): an arboreal protoxerine (Heliosciurus rufobrachium), an arboreal sciurine (the eastern gray squirrel, Sciurus carolinensis) and four marmotine ground squirrels. Three of the marmotines are closely related species: Callospermophilus lateralis, Otospermophilus variegatus and O. beecheyi, the other is Ammospermophilus leucurus. Relationships among species (Fabre et al. 2012; Zelditch et al. 2015) are shown in Fig. 1 . Sample sizes are given in Table 1 . Adult weights range over an order of magnitude and species span the continuum from precocial to altricial. One species, S. fulviventer, is known to be highly precocial and another, Heliosciurus rufobrachium probably also is, given information available for protoxerines including other Heliosciurus (Emmons 1979; Viljoen and Du Toit 1985; Viljoen 1981; Hayssen 2008) . The other species are altricial.

The ontogenetic series for the two muroids come from laboratory populations. The laboratory mice are C57BL/6 J mice raised for an unrelated project. All animals were housed and euthanized following standard protocols approved by the University Committee on the Use and Care of Animals of the University of Michigan. Specimens were collected at 2-day intervals during the first postnatal week, then at 3-6-day intervals until P24 (approximately 3 days after weaning). Adult size and shape are represented by individuals at 86 days. To examine the poorly ossified mandibles, those of the youngest animals (between birth and weaning) were cleared and stained; these are the same Fig. 1 Phylogenetic relationships among the eight species of myomorphs and sciuromorphs based on analyses of rodents (Fabre et al. 2012 ) and sciurids (Zelditch et al. 2015) individuals analyzed in a prior study of the ontogeny of mandibular shape (Swiderski and Zelditch 2013) , which gives additional details on the protocol used for clearing and staining and for photography. The sample of S. fulviventer comprises the offspring of wild-caught parents bred and reared in the colony at the Michigan State University Museum, and killed at 10-day intervals, starting with the day of birth. These animals come from the same colony as those analyzed in previous studies on the ontogeny of craniofacial morphology (Zelditch et al. 2003a) .

The ontogenetic series of squirrels are from natural populations, with the exception of two infant O. beecheyi. These two were born in a laboratory colony, one was a 7-day-old and the other a 14-day-old, both are figured and described by Hall (1926) . In these two individuals, the mandibular incisor has erupted and is comparable to that of a 5-day old M. musculus, but shorter and narrower than that of a 1-day old S. fulviventer. Two other individuals are at a comparable stage of dental development, although their ages are unknown and two others have more fully erupted incisors but the alveolar ridge is not yet detectable as a ridge. The ages of all other individuals are unknown and there are few very young infants available in museum collections drawn from natural populations. Two other samples contain individuals that have incompletely erupted incisors and a weakly developed alveolar ridge (S. carolinensis, H. rufobrachium). In other samples, P 4 is already erupting in the youngest animals (A. leucurus, C. lateralis), or M 1 is already erupting in the youngest animal and M 2 is erupting in the next youngest (O. variegatus).

Mandibles were photographed in lateral view; those of the youngest individuals from museum collections were photographed and measured twice on both sides to minimize measurement error owing to the difficulty of both photographing and measuring these specimens. Ten anatomically distinct landmarks were digitized on each photograph (Fig. 2) . These include the mental foramen, openings of the incisor alveoli, tips of the posterior processes, and locations where those processes are connected to the ramus (or to the sheets of bone between processes). These provide limited information about the curvature of the jaw, so to incorporate that information into the analysis, additional points (semilandmarks) were sampled along the curves of the posterior processes, along the diastema (including dorsal margin of the horizontal ramus between incisor and molar and ventral margin of the horizontal ramus). Landmark and semilandmarks were digitized in tpsDig 2.17 (Rohlf 2013) .

Landmark configurations were aligned by a generalized Procrustes superimposition (Rohlf and Slice 1990) to remove variation in location, orientation (rotation) in the photographic plane, and scale. The coordinates of the semilandmarks contain an additional nuisance parameter (position along the curve), which was removed by sliding them to minimize bending energy, a measure of local deformation (Bookstein 1997; Green 1996) . As our measure of size, we used centroid size, the square root of the summed squared distances of all points (landmarks plus semilandmarks) from the centroid of each configuration. Superimposition was done in geomorph 2.14 (Adams and Otarola-Castillo 2013), a package for geometric morphometrics in R 3.

To analyze ontogeny, we used linear regression, a method that presumes that shape is linearly related to size. However, a previous analysis found that mandibular shape ontogeny of M. musculus is not linearly related to size throughout ontogeny and that the ontogenetic trajectory of shape curves markedly in early postnatal development (Swiderski and Zelditch 2013) . Thus, we first analyze the Configurations of landmarks and semilandmarks analyzed in this study. The 10 landmarks (large circles) include the mental foramen, openings of incisor alveoli, tips of the posterior processes, and locations where those processes are connected to the ramus (or to the sheets of bone between processes); semilandmarks (small circles) provide information about curvature along posterior processes and the diastema relationship between size and shape in the three most complete ontogenetic series to determine whether the relationship between size and shape is (multivariately) linear. To that end, we examined the allometry scores for each specimen, which are obtained by projecting each individual's data on the vector of allometric coefficients, plotted relative to ln-transformed centroid size (LCS). We also examined the residuals (RSC1) to determine if they curve, suggesting an age-related pattern in the deviations from the linear models. These analyses were done using the plotAllometry function in geomorph. The relationship between size and shape and the ontogenetic trajectory of shape are visibly nonlinear in both M. musculus and O. beecheyi, especially at the smallest sizes ( Fig. 3) . We thus omitted the three youngest age-classes of M. musculus and the four smallest individuals of O. beecheyi. Although the residuals are heterogeneous in the sample of S. fulviventer, they suggest that there is another source of variation within the population rather than age-dependent allometries. Given these results, when predicting shape at the youngest comparable developmental stage, we predicted shape at the size when the incisor is nearly erupted. In all species save S. fulviventer, jaw size at this stage is appropriately 70 % of the adult size; in S. fulviventer, it is just 53 % of adult jaw size and jaw size in that species does not reach a value comparable to the other species until M 1 has erupted, 10 days after birth.

To determine whether species differ in shape and in their ontogenetic trajectories, we fit the model that shape depends on ''Species'' and LCS using a Procrustes Anova (Goodall 1991; Klingenberg and McIntyre 1998) , which is equivalent to a permutational MANOVA of the distance matrix, with that matrix comprising pairwise Procrustes distances between specimens (Anderson and ter Braak 2003) . Interspecific differences between the ontogenies are inferred when the ''Species'' 9 LCS interaction term is statistically significant, which could indicate differences in developmental rate and/or the directions of the allometric trajectories. A statistically significant interaction means that the shape differences among species depend on size, so to analyze the disparities of infants and adults, the mean shapes of infants and adults for each species were determined using the species-specific regression equation.

To determine whether trajectories differ in orientation and/or length, we compared both the directions of ontogeny and the rate at which shape changes per unit change in size. The difference in direction is quantified by the angle between trajectories; the cosine of the angle is the correlation between two vectors (calculated as the inner products between normalized vectors). To determine whether the angle is greater than expected by chance, we used a permutation test of the residuals of the reduced model, i.e., a model lacking the intercept term. By permuting the residuals of the reduced model, the main effect(s) are held constant; the observed angle can then be compared to the distribution of the random values to assess statistical significance (Adams and Collyer 2009; Anderson and ter Braak 2003; Collyer et al. 2014) . The same statistical approach can be used to test for differences in developmental rate, which is a rate of shape change relative to a unit change in LCS. These statistical analyses of the ontogenetic trajectories of shape were done using the advanced.procD.lm function in the geomorph package. To test for differences in length, we predicted the shape for each species at the smallest comparable stage and at the mean adult body size; we used the predicted shapes (plus residuals) in pairwise tests of the differences in mean shape. The comparison of trajectory lengths was done using the trajectory.analysis function in geomorph. In addition, we used another statistical approach that has been used in several comparative analyses of ontogeny, that of comparing the angle between species to the range of angles that can be obtained by bootstrap resampling of each species' ontogeny (e.g., Zelditch et al. 2000; Angielczyk and Feldman 2013; Sanfelice and Freitas 2007; Urosevic et al. 2013) . This is done by calculating residuals from the full model; residuals are bootstrapped to produce two bootstrap sets, and these are added to the expected value for shape at each specimen's size. The angle between these two vectors is calculated for each iteration of the bootstrap, yielding a distribution of the angles that could be obtained by resampling within a single population. The angle is judged to be significantly larger than 0 if it lies beyond the 95 % confidence interval for both bootstrap sets. This alternative procedure is useful because it also gives an estimate of the reliability of the angles.

To analyze allometric disparity, we conducted a principal components analysis of the ontogenetic vectors. In this analysis, the data for each species consists of coefficients, i.e., each row in the data matrix contains the allometric coefficients for one species. A principal components analysis of this matrix thus displays the major dimensions of variation in allometric vectors.

To compare the level of disparity of infants to adults, we measured disparity as the variance of the species' mean shapes, estimated at the youngest and oldest developmentally comparable stages. To quantify the ontogenetic change in disparity we subtracted the disparity of the juveniles from that of the adults; a positive value for this difference in disparity would indicate that adults are more disparate than infants. To determine if the difference in disparity is significant, we used a permutation procedure following Adams and Nistri (2010) . The test is done by randomizing the predicted morphologies for all individuals with respect to size, then estimating new predicted morphologies. Disparity at each age is calculated from these predicted shapes, and the difference in disparity is calculated for each permutation, yielding a distribution of 999 differences in disparity. The proportion of randomly generated differences in disparity that is equal to or larger than the observed value is treated as the significance level.
body_text.section: Comparing the Level of Disparity Between Developmental Stages

body_text.text: To quantify the impact of changes in ontogeny on disparity of adults, we first asked whether the disparity in one ontogenetic parameter alone can generate levels of disparity comparable to those resulting from variation in all three. We then asked whether removing the disparity in a single ontogenetic parameter affects the observed level of disparity. To construct these models, we fixed the value of one or more parameters to be equal in all species, thereby removing that component of developmental disparity. For example, to assess the impact of divergent directions of ontogenetic trajectories, we first fixed only the direction of the trajectories to be the same in all species, removing the disparity generated only by variation in direction. Then we fixed both the shape of the infant and the length of the ontogenetic trajectory to be the same in all species; consequently, only the direction of the trajectory varies.
body_text.section: Quantifying the Impact of Disparate Ontogenies on Shape Disparity

body_text.text: To estimate the disparity that could be generated prenatally by ontogenetic trajectories that diverge by no more than the ones we observe postnatally, we simulated ontogenies that differ solely in direction over a size range from 30 to 50 % of adult size. These analyses are not intended to produce realistic predictions of shape at those sizes; the aim is simply to determine how much disparity could be generated by trajectories that diverge by no more than the ones we observed, were developmental rates as high as prenatal rates. Based on our estimates for size of the youngest animals in our most complete ontogenetic series, O. beecheyi is comparatively small at birth; our youngest specimen is 40 % of adult size; the laboratory mice neonates are 47 % of adult size and those of S. fulviventer are 53 % of adult size. An estimate for mandibular length of b Fig. 3 Allometry scores and the major dimension of the residuals from the regression of shape on size. The deviations from linearity of allometry scores relative to size (left) indicate a nonlinear relationship between shape and size; deviations from linearity of the residuals (right) indicate that the ontogenetic trajectory of shape changes its direction over ontogeny O. beecheyi embryos when remnants of Meckel's cartilage are still visible is approximately 21 % of adult length and coronoid height is approximately 7 % of adult height (Hall 1926) . Thus, our estimates of mandibular size of embryos are probably too high, but the results can be regarded as conservative estimates of the disparity that could be generated prenatally.
body_text.section: Quantifying the Impact of Disparate Ontogenies on Shape Disparity

body_text.text: To assess the similarity of the morphospaces occupied by infants and adults, we compared the two main dimensions of the morphospaces. We calculated the angles between the first two principal components of both spaces (comparing PC1 of the morphospace of infants to both PC1 and PC2 of the morphospace of adults because they may have the same axes that differ only in the proportion of variance explained; and also comparing PC2 of the morphospace of infants to both PC1 and PC2 of the adults). To quantify the similarity between subspaces rather than individual axes, we used Krzanowski's (2000) metric, first quantifying the similarity between a two-dimensional subspace, then a four-dimensional one. This measure is the sum of the eigenvalues of the matrix S

body_text.text: where A and B contain a subset of eigenvectors. The sum of the eigenvalues of S ranges from zero, which indicates no similarity between the subspaces, to a value equal to the number of dimensions, which indicates identical subspaces. This comparison between subspaces was done using the krzanowski.test function in the R package MCMCglmm (Hadfield 2010) . In addition to these analyses of overall disparity, we conducted pairwise comparisons to determine if species differ more (or less) from each other as adults than they did as infants and if they diverge in different directions as adults than as infants. Formally, these analyses are the same as the ones done to compare ontogenetic trajectories. Rather than comparing the change from infant to adult between species, these analyses compare the interspecific differences between developmental stages. These analyses used the trajectory analysis function in the geomorph package.
body_text.section: Comparing the Structure of Disparity Between Developmental Stages

body_text.text: Procrustes Anova indicates there are significant effects of size, species and their interaction on shape (Table 2) . In pairwise comparisons of infant shapes (Table 3) , all species differ statistically significantly (P B 0.001 for all pairwise comparisons). The distances between some species are not large; e.g., those between the three most closely related ground squirrels, and between the two distantly related arboreal species (H. rufobrachium, S. carolinensis). The differences between the ontogenetic trajectories of shape are typically modest even when statistically significant (Table 4 ). The angles range from just 16°-20°in comparisons between the three most closely related ground squirrels to 42.6°(between the two myomorphs). The two methods for assessing the statistical significance of the differences yield different results; in contrast to the statistical results reported in Table 4 , the one based on bootstrapped residuals finds that all differences exceeding 18°i n Table 4 are greater than expected by chance except for comparisons to H. rufobrachium (no comparison to that species is statistically significant using this method). The most striking similarity between the ontogenies of shape is the general deepening of the horizontal ramus relative to its length, (evident in what appears to be a shortening of the mandible anteriorly) and the tremendous deepening of the angular process (Fig. 4) . In most species, there is also a substantial increase in the width of the coronoid process, as well as a reorientation of that process to be more erect.

What varies among the trajectories is more evident in a plot of allometric disparity. PC1 of the sample comprising all eight species (Fig. 5a ) accounts for 36.5 % of the variation among trajectories, distinguishing those that differ in the spatial distribution of deepening of the horizontal ramus, curvature of the coronoid and widening and reorientation of the condyloid process. PC2 accounts for 24.2 % of the variation in trajectories and distinguishes among trajectories that increase squareness of the angular process and robustness of the basal region of the coronoid while decreasing the elongation of the angular process and the excavation of the notch between coronoid and condyloid processes. For the sample restricted to the six squirrel species (Fig. 5b) , PC1 accounts for 38.5 % of the variation among trajectories with the three closely related ground squirrels sharing relatively greater elongation of the condyloid, narrowing the base of the coronoid while increasing its curvature and increasing elongation of the anterior ramus. PC2 accounts for 29 % of the variation among trajectories, and reflects greater increase in the height and robustness of coronoid, less shallowing of the notch between condyloid and angular and greater elongation with less squaring of the angular.

Most species also differ in rates of shape change relative to an increase of one unit of size as well as in the overall length of the ontogenetic trajectories ( Fig. 6 ; Table 5 ). The lowest rate (that of S. fulviventer) is just 59 % that of the highest (that of A. leucurus) and the shortest trajectory (that of O. variegatus) is 67 % of the longest (that of S. fulviventer). Species that develop at a low rate (such as S. fulviventer) can have long ontogenetic trajectories because they develop slowly relative to size but grow over a larger size range. However, the two largest-bodied species, H. rufobrachium and O. variegatus, have the shortest ontogenetic trajectories.

Disparity of adults of the full sample is just 10 % higher than that of infants (Fig. 7) , which is not statistically significant (P = 0.106). The same pattern is seen for the sample of squirrels; adult disparity is nearly 9 % higher, but that difference is not statistically significant (P = 0.245).

In simulations of disparity from a single source, disparity is far higher if it all arises prenatally than if it arises only from either differences in the length or direction of postnatal ontogeny (Fig. 8) . Disparity arising solely from differences in trajectory length is an order of magnitude lower than that arising solely from disparity in direction. Length does matter however, because the disparity arising from variation in direction of ontogeny depends on the length of Angles are above the diagonal; P values for the statistical significance of the difference in trajectories are below the diagonal. Sigmo = Sigmodon fulviventer; Mus = Mus musculus domesticus (C57/BL6 strain); Carol = Sciurus carolinensis, Helio = Heliosciurus rufobrachium; Ammo = Ammospermophilus leucurus; Callo = Callospermophilus lateralis; Var = Otospermophilus variegatus, Beech = O. beecheyi the trajectories: more is generated when divergent trajectories are long than when they are short. The least arises when the lengths are fixed to the shortest value, that of O. variegatus (D = 0.0013) and the most arises when they are fixed to the longest length, that of S. fulviventer (D = 0.0029). If the average disparity due solely to disparity in direction (0.00267), which is just 34 % of the disparity generated prenatally, is added to the disparity of infants, it would produce a statistically significant ontogenetic increase in disparity (P \ 0.025). The same pattern is evident in the analysis restricted to squirrels. Disparity that arises from variation in both lengths and directions of postnatal growth, starting from an invariant infant morphology, is far lower than if disparity arises from variation in prenatal development plus either disparity in length or direction (Fig. 9) . Disparity is comparable to the observed value when it arises from a combination of variation in prenatal development and the direction of postnatal ontogenetic trajectories (with length held constant); under those conditions, D = 0.0075, comparable to the observed value. The same pattern is seen in squirrels except that the combination of variation in infant morphology and the directions of the ontogenetic trajectory, yields D = 0.0056, slightly higher than observed adult disparity.
body_text.section: Quantifying the Impact of Disparate Ontogenies on Shape Disparity

body_text.text: Predicting the disparity that would arise from following the postnatal ontogenetic trajectories over the size range of late embryonic stages yields far higher disparity of infant mandibles (D = 0.0110); than observed (D = 0.0068). Similarly, if the analysis is restricted to squirrels, the disparity of late embryonic mandibles (D = 0.0105) is more than twice as high as the observed value for infants (D = 0.0049). Extending those same trajectories to the adult sizes yields adult disparity (D = 0.0928) is not only far higher than the observed value, (D = 0.0076), it also increases nine-fold over ontogeny. For squirrels, the value Fig. 4 Ontogenies of shape for the eight species of myomorphs and sciurids from the eruption of the deciduous premolar, P 4 (squirrels) or molar M 1 (myomorphs) to the shape of the adult jaw at mean adult size is far lower (D = 0.0486) but that too is an order of magnitude higher than the observed value (D = 0.0052) and disparity increases nearly five-fold over ontogeny.
body_text.section: Quantifying the Impact of Disparate Ontogenies on Shape Disparity

body_text.text: PC1 of the morphospace of infant shapes (Fig. 10a) , which accounts for 42.1 % of their variation, is aligned with the difference between the myomorphs and the ground squirrels. Compared to the myomorphs, the mandible of the ground squirrels is generally more slender except for the angular process, which is more robust and squared. PC2, which accounts for 35.8 % of infant shape variation, is aligned with the differences between arboreal squirrels and the terrestrial species (ground squirrels and myomorphs). The arboreal squirrels' mandibles are more robust anteriorly and their more rectangular angular process is already evident. For the sample restricted to the six species of squirrels (Fig. 10b) , PC1 of the infant morphospace, by itself, accounts for 73 % of the variance and PC2 accounts for 12.2 %. PC1 of the difference between ground squirrel and tree squirrel infants is similar in pattern to PC1 of the difference between ground squirrel and myomorph infants, except that the two groups of squirrels differ little in coronoid shape and differ more in robustness of the anterior mandible and orientation of the angular process. PC2 of this space reflects variation among ground squirrels in orientation of the coronoid process and length of the condyloid process.
body_text.section: Comparing the Structure of Disparity Between Developmental Stages

body_text.text: As adults, all species differ in shape (Table 6) , as they did as infants. PC1 of the morphospace of adult shapes (Fig. 11a) , which accounts for 45.0 % of the variation, is aligned with the difference between the myomorphs and the ground squirrels. As adults, compared to myomorphs, the ground squirrel mandible is somewhat more slender generally, but at this stage, it is primarily the coronoid process that is exceptionally slender and elongated (and curved) in the ground squirrels. The angular of ground squirrel adults, like that of the infants, is more robust and squared. PC2, which accounts for 34.7 % of the variation in the morphospace of adults, is more closely aligned with the differences between arboreal squirrels and the terrestrial ones. The arboreal squirrels' mandible is more robust, especially anteriorly, the notch between the coronoid and condyloid process is shallower, and the angular process is shorter and projects more ventrally than posteriorly, leading to a more vertical curve from the condyloid to angular process. PC1 of the adult morphospace of squirrels (Fig. 11b ) accounts for 72 % of the variation in shape, with ground squirrels being generally more slender except in the angular process, which is both deeper and extends more posteriorly. PC2 accounts for 18.6 % of the variation among these adult squirrels, with S. carolinensis, O. variegatus and O. beecheyi having more robust jaws with relatively less square angular processes than H. rufobrachium or C. lateralis, respectively.
body_text.section: Comparing the Structure of Disparity Between Developmental Stages

body_text.text: The main dimensions of the morphospaces are conserved over ontogeny; the angle between PC1 of the infant morphospace and PC1 of the adult morphospace is just 22.67°, and for PC2, it is just 29.07°and Krzanowski's sum of the eigenvalues of S (a metric of subspace similarity) of 1.65, compared to the maximum possible value of 2.0 for Fig. 6 Rates of shape change and lengths of ontogenetic trajectories. The rate of shape change is units of Procrustes distance per unit logtransformed centroid size. The length of the vector is the Procrustes distance between the shape at the outset of the observed phase (just prior to eruption of M 1 in myomorphs eruption of P 4 in squirrels), and the adult shape this two-dimensional subspace. Similarly, for the analysis limited to the six species of squirrels, the angle between PC1 of the infant and adult morphospaces, the axis that accounts for more than 70 % of the variation at both ages, is just 18.35°and Krzanowski's sum of eigenvalues of S is 1.128, supporting the conclusion that the adult and infant morphospaces have an axis in common, the one that distinguishes arboreal from ground squirrels. Comparisons between other PCs yield large angles; for PC2, it is 61.6°a nd the values are similar if PC2 is compared to PC3 (61.72°for comparisons between PC3 of infants to PC2 of adults, and 54.64°for PC3 of adults to PC2 of infants).
body_text.section: Comparing the Structure of Disparity Between Developmental Stages

body_text.text: Despite the high similarity between the main dimensions of the infant and adult morphospaces, interspecific differences are typically not growth invariant-the vectors extending between species at the two developmental stages frequently rotate (Table 7 ) and several species diverge or converge over ontogeny (Table 8) .
body_text.section: Comparing the Structure of Disparity Between Developmental Stages

body_text.text: Plotting the ontogenetic trajectories within a common morphospace (based on all individuals) shows that, within this low-dimensional plot, some species get closer and others diverge further over ontogeny and, in some cases, the change is primarily (or only) in the direction in which the species diverge (Fig. 12 ).
body_text.section: Comparing the Structure of Disparity Between Developmental Stages

body_text.text: Our analysis confirms the perplexing pattern often reported in comparative studies of ontogeny: disparity is high at birth or shortly thereafter and does not increase significantly over ontogeny even when species differ in both Sigmo = Sigmodon fulviventer; Mus = Mus musculus domesticus (C57/BL6 strain); Carol = Sciurus carolinensis, Helio = Heliosciurus rufobrachium; Ammo = Ammospermophilus leucurus; Callo = Callospermophilus lateralis; Var = Otospermophilus variegatus, Beech = O. beecheyi Fig. 7 Disparity of infants (I) and adults (A), measured as the variance of mean shape at the two developmental stages, for all 8 species (left) and for the 6 squirrel species (right) Fig. 8 Disparity arising from simulated ontogenies with a single free parameter; the other two are fixed, for all 8 species (left) and for the 6 squirrel species (right). The height of the bar shows the mean value for disparity arising from variation in the one free parameter. P = the disparity of infants, arising prior to the youngest observed stage; L = the disparity arising solely from variation in the length of ontogenetic trajectories; D = disparity arising solely from variation in the direction of ontogenetic trajectories patterns and rates of postnatal growth. Not only is disparity nearly constant in magnitude, it is also nearly constant in the main dimensions of disparity. That constancy in both level and major dimensions of variation is not due to the negligible disparity introduced by postnatal growth. The disparity contributed by variation in trajectory length is indeed negligible; but that due to differences in postnatal allometry could increase disparity by 30-40 % of that produced prenatally. Disparity is nevertheless constant because the disparity generated postnatally is not added to that present at birth; instead, it modifies differences present at birth. The main dimensions are constant but in half the interspecific comparisons, disparity either increases or decreases, with increases balancing decreases and in 40 % of the comparisons, the direction in which the species differ rotates by at least 40°. Had species followed the same trajectories throughout the entire process of development and growth, disparity would increase continually, albeit at a decreasing rate. The simulation of constant growth rates also shows that the high disparity evident near birth is not due to the greater flexibility of early development because, in our simulation, early and late developmental trajectories are the same but the disparity at birth is twice the observed value and that of adults is an order of magnitude higher. Disparity does not increase postnatally because ontogenies are not strictly linear; the disparity generated postnatally counteracts that produced earlier. What limits the progressive accumulation of disparity is the curvature of ontogenetic trajectories, a curvature presumably due to ontogenetic changes in the spatial distribution of rates of bone deposition and resorption. Given our sparse sample of rodents, we cannot conclude that disparity is constant over postnatal rodent ontogeny. Clearly, our estimates of adult disparity are not credible estimates of rodent or even squirrel morphological disparity-we did not sample the most divergent squirrels, such as the specialized insectivore (Rhinosciurus laticaudatus), or bark-gleaning miniatures with their dramatically reduced coronoid processes or the exceptionally robust hard-endocarp specialists or flying squirrels. Moreover, three of the sampled species come from one of the least disparate clades of squirrels (Otospermophilus ? Callospermophilus). Obviously, our two distantly related and morphologically distinct myomorphs cannot provide a realistic estimate of the disparity of that group. Considering those limitations, what is surprising is that the range of allometric disparity in this small sample of rodents is so similar to those found in studies of other amniotes (Table 9 ). Most of the other studies examine craniofacial or mandibular ontogeny and those generally yield similar results; the angle between the craniofacial ontogenies of Mus musculus domesticus and Sigmodon fulviventer is 42.2° (Zelditch et al. 2003a) , nearly identical to the 42.6°f ound herein for the mandible. A few species differ from one another by more than 60°, such as humans from other great apes, and several anthropoids from others in scapular ontogeny, but such large angles are rare when ontogenies are well-sampled. Not surprisingly, closely related and morphologically similar species, like Otospermophilus and Callospermophilus, differ little in their ontogenies, but even distantly related and morphologically disparate species rarely differ by more than 50°and it may not take long to diverge by that much considering that there are angles of 40°between species of Marmota and the crown age for that clade is only 5.8 Ma (Zelditch et al. 2015) .

The range of allometric disparity found in our sample (and studies summarized in Table 9 ) might seem extraordinarily large in light of previous broad comparisons of rodents. In the study of South American muroids, Voss and Marcus (1992) found that congeneric species differ, on average, by just 11.9°and species from different tribes differ, on average, by just 15.8°. Those are close to angles reported for comparisons between myomorphs (averaging 16.9°) and hystricomorphs (averaging 17.2°) (Wilson and Sanchez-Villagra 2010) , both of which are far higher than differences between sciuromophs, which average a mere 8.9° (Wilson 2013) . But those very small angles are measured on a different scale. In studies of the ontogeny of shape, randomly related vectors differ, on average, by 90°b ut vectors of allometric coefficients for size measurements, which were used in the broad studies of rodents, cannot differ by 90°because allometric coefficients for size Fig. 9 Disparity arising from simulated ontogenies with a single fixed parameter; the other two are free, for all 8 species (left) and for the 6 squirrel species (right). The height of the bar shows the mean value for disparity arising from variation in the two free parameters when the indicated one is fixed. P = the disparity of infants arising prior to the youngest observed stage; L = the disparity arising solely from variation in the length of ontogenetic trajectories; D = disparity arising solely from variation in the direction of ontogenetic trajectories measurements are almost invariably positive numbers (unless the measurements actually shrink in development). Because they are positive numbers, and the sum of the products of corresponding coefficients are necessarily positive, they cannot sum to zero, hence the arccosine of that sum (the angle between trajectories) cannot be 90°. Instead, they may be less than 4°, as in comparisons to squirrels that are nearly isometric (Wilson 2013) , rising to C20°for the vectors of more heterogeneous coefficients characteristic of the other suborders, or even as high as 40°w

hen the data include dental measurements that do not grow (Voss and Marcus 1992) . Unfortunately, because of those differences in scale, the results of these studies cannot be combined to yield insights into the evolutionary timing of allometric divergence. Our results do not contradict the inference that allometric disparity is lower in squirrels than in myomorphs, but due to our limited sampling, we cannot estimate either the mean or range of allometric disparity in that clade.

Exceptionally low allometric disparity could be one explanation for morphologically conservative groups. In particular, in the most extreme case of no allometric disparity or divergence in early development, all of disparity would necessarily originate from differences in adult body size and/or in rates and timings of development. Those sources contribute only negligible disparity in our simulation, perhaps because the lengths of the ontogenetic trajectories in our sample differ so little. In groups that span more than an order of magnitude in body size, or that differ more in their life-histories than precocial and altricial rodents do, the disparity arising from ontogenetic scaling or heterochrony may be greater. Yet, our estimate of the disparity produced by variation solely in trajectory length may not be unrealistic considering how close it is to the disparity of adult shape of Podacris lizards, which apparently do evolve solely by heterochrony (Piras et al. 2011; Urosevic et al. 2013) . In that group, disparity (D) is approximately 0.0004 (Fig. 4, Urosevic et al. 2013) , close the value of 0.0003 obtained from our simulations. Several studies of primates have argued for a pervasive pattern of ontogenetic scaling or heterochrony (e.g., Shea 1983 Shea , 1989 Marroig 2007; Ravosa 1992 ) but they typically do not contend that disparity arises solely from those processes. No doubt heterochrony can generate far more disparity in groups that have a distinct larval phase, with some species retaining that larval morphology to sexual maturity, but in groups that have continuous life-cycles, ontogenetic scaling and heterochrony may be a cause of highly conservative morphologies.

Short of the extreme case of no allometric disparity at any developmental stage, it is difficult to predict the impact of allometric disparity on the disparity of adult morphology. Wilson (2013) concludes that squirrels have low allometric disparity and that their conservative ontogenies constrain adult disparity, and also that squirrels are conservative in their covariance structures (contrasting the general pattern of conserved covariance structures found in other mammalian groups). However, conservative covariance matrices were not documented in that study and postnatal allometric disparity, by itself, is not a predictor of morphological disparity. The range of allometric disparity within Marmota is nearly as large as in the rodents analyzed by us, yet, the disparity of adult mandibular shape in Marmota is just 0.00086 (Zelditch et al. 2015) , nearly an order of magnitude lower than in our sample (0.00748). The mean may be a better predictor than the range and no estimate of the mean is available for Marmota but there are two other studies that report the angles and the disparity of b Fig. 10 Morphospace of infant jaw shape based on the principal components of variation among species in mean jaw shape prior to the eruption of the deciduous premolar, P 4 (squirrels) or molar M 1 (myomorphs). a Disparity of all eight species; b disparity of the six species of squirrels shape, one for eared seals (Sanfelice and Freitas 2007) and the other for lacertid lizards (Urosevic et al. 2013) . That mean is highest in eared seals (42.1°vs. 28.1°for our sample and 25.8°for lacertid lizards). Adult shape disparity is also highest for eared seals, D = 0.0123. That value is close to twice the disparity of infants in our study and also far higher than the adult disparity of lacertid skull shape, D = 0.0021, an increase of 40-50 % over the disparity of infants, but it is just 30 % of the adult disparity of our sample of rodents. In groups that have an exceptionally large range of ontogenetic directions, disparity sometimes decreases substantially over ontogeny (Zelditch et al. 2003b; Adams and Nistri 2010) . In one case, that of the damselfish premaxilla, shape disparity increases but by less than that of other structures that are less disparate in their allometries (Frederich and Vandewalle 2011) . Disparate ontogenetic allometries can thus greatly increase the disparity of morphology but they can also decrease it. The impact of disparate allometries for morphological disparity depends both on the lengths of the ontogenetic trajectories and on their orientation relative to trajectories of early development.

Studies of allometric disparity contain little information about constraints on morphological disparity because there are many explanations for low disparity. Ontogenetic trajectories might be conservative either because of their low evolvability or functional constraints, thus the conservatism of those trajectories raise precisely the same questions that conservatism of morphologies do. Answering them for ontogeny is far more difficult because doing so would require estimating the heritable variation of trajectories, not just characterizing age-related change in mean shape or form. The idea that conservative ontogenies constrain morphology may also reverse the actual causality of the constraints: low disparity of squirrel ontogenetic allometries may not be a constraint so much as the developmental route to a conservative end.
